author: Iguanaboy
title: best monster fighters set ever
review:
This set has so many good things about it.

Pros

  • 2 exclusive minifigures
  • comes with set 40076 if ordered online 
  • many minifigures
  • other pros

Cons

  • none

This is a great set.

author: Bobby87
title: Crowning piece to the Monster Fighters
review:
I think, non of the set of the current Monster Fighters theme was so much anticipated like this one. I got the luck to buy one at the Cologne LEGO-store last saturday. After building it over the cours of the last two days it is time to take a closer look and summe up my thoughts about this set.  

Pros

  • The minifigures: The ghosts, the Vampire and the Vampire's bride are known from    other sets, but the zombie chef and the frankenstein's monster like butler are exclusiv to this set. The first is more like a variation of the zombie driver from other sets. But I think the butler is the minifigure, that takes the  cake in this set.
  • The Build and details: It is a real fun to see the strukture and shape of the house rising and finding so many small and well thought details, like the stairs to the attic, the different bared windows.
  • The overall look: The finished Haunted House looks exacly like this, the quintessential Haunted House. Due to the fact that it opens in the middle, connected by hinges, the house has four solide walls. This also make it look great next to the modular town buildings. (Of cours a bit seperated by a creepy forest and/or the doorway which comes with the house and adds great to the look.)

Cons

  • The walls: During the bulding the walls, especially on the first floor are build as very high but small parts. Due to this, they tend to break off if you touch them while for example fitting in the windows.
  • The windows: The buliding of the barred windows get a bit repetitious, as you build basicly the same window, with very little diverences, nine times at times of the buildingprogress

All in all the Haunted House is, at least in my oppinion, a must have for every collector of the "special gems" of LEGO. In my collection it has already found its place next tho the Imperial Flagship and the modular town buildings.

author: Harmonious_Building
title: The price tag is probably the scariest part.
review:
It's a bit hard to justify the $180 price tag on LEGO's first Haunted House, as cool as it is. The piececount is no greater than that of a $150 modular building, so I suppose there is a certain greater desierability as far as the included Minifigs are concerned. Fortunately, LEGO decided to soften the blow a little with the concurrent release and bundling of the Zombie Car (40076), which has such a great symbiosis with the Haunted House that it almost negates the extra cost.

 

The Haunted House sort of masquerades as a run-down version of a modular building, though it is clearly meant to stand alone. Certainly, it compares favourably in terms of size to, say, the Grand Emporium (10211), but lack of Technic pegs or anywhere to attach them to means that this building stays separate - after all, who wants to live next to a Haunted House anyway?

 

The other difference between this set and the town modular buildings is the fact that the floors are not constructed as removable layers. In lieu of this, the Haunted House opts for a more traditional "dollhouse" design, as pictured, and there are pros and cons to this. The pro would be that all of the floors and furniture are accessible for purposes of actually playing with the house, while the con, I guess, is that realism suffers somewhat in this configuration. I wouldn't have opposed to the house being both of a dollhouse design and with removable layers, but I guess that might be asking too much.

 

The instructions make the somewhat curious choice of telling you to build all of the furniture first and then place it inside the house as the build goes on, which means that you can start on bag 2 first if you want to get right into building the house and keep bag 1 separate, using them for furniture as necessary. I suppose there are certain continuity advantages to this, but it did make the build seem a little boring, particularly the second level. The builds also demand a fair amount of trust from the builder, in that windows and pillars are left hanging precariously on one- or two-stud blocks until long "reinforcers" are placed much later. Be advised - it is highly recommended that you build on a hard surface for this reason.

 

There are some stickers, though not too many as to be annoying. Strangely, my sticker page came without one of the portrait stickers, which kind of stinks, but it's not a tragedy. I didn't both to apply the window stickers, and I don't feel that the overall look suffered any because of it.

 

I won't go into any of the details regarding the Minifigs or the play features, since those are all depicted quite clearly in the promotional images right on this site. I don't own any of the Monster Fighters sets, nor do I own any of the previous "horror" Minifigs from previous Collectable Minifig collections, so all of them were a novelty to me; I've been saying for years that the ghost needs to come back, and I'm so happy to see him make a triumphant return. I have a lot of leftover Undead from Fantasy Era sets, too, so now they have a house to live in.

 

The final display looks great, and the front gate is a very welcome addition to the set as a whole. The house does a very good job at communicating texture and decay from shiny new LEGO bricks, which I think is a great achievement, and it looks suitably macabre and will therefore get a smile out of anyone with tastes leaning in that direction. I guess you could say that it's creepy and it's kooky, mysterious and spooky...

author: flynnofilm
title: Munsters' Inspired Haunted House Works!
review:
This set is the crown jewel of the year. I am 35, my wife is 30, and my son is 4(1/2). We have been sold on this set since we saw it in our catalog earlier this summer and have been saving. Then we saw the video of the designer presenting the model, and knew it would be something to buy as soon as it came out Sept.1. We even just went to Lego Kids Fest to try and get it a day early, no luck but here we are :)

We have been building in shifts for 72 hours and been having a blast as a trio. 
Once completed, the "dollhouse" ability of the structure to open and close really won us over for repeat and extended play. Check out the pictures I have attached which takes you from the last or top floor all the way through final detailing, placement on a Lego table, extending the build with a secure basement/dungeon, and adding a few other pieces of flair from our collection.

The theme of Irregularity in the set is refreshing for Lego sets in a completely unexpected way. You can see from the pictures that it was not only to fun to build and that it has a ton of great features, but that it was easy to expand upon.

I should address the only things this set does not include as well...a pair of coffins...chains... we were lucky to have also gotten the free "over $75 purchase" of the zombie chauffeur, who you can see having been immediately added into this mix. This is why "parts" gets a 4 not 5. It was so close to absolute perfection, on par with any of the "Star Wars" or "Kindgoms" set. 

Plus it will be adding a great amount of diversity to our collection moving forward. Many of these bricks are new this year and we are very happy to have them. Tan and gray side-etched "brick wall" bricks, lime green pieces, and the whole Monster Family (In Black and White, lol) really make this set one to take the time to save up and get.

I tried to manually add a bunch of photos, no luck.

You can instead check them out here (Facebook link-Scroll down)

author: arl100
title: Welcome to the Haunted House
review:
LEGO has most certainly done themselves proud with a set of this calibre, it is an excellent piece to have and clearly shows a lot of effort has gone into the layout and design of the house itself. They have clearly wanted to appeal to a greater audience here, as well as general lego enthusiasts they have opened the door to fans of the old TV series (Munsters, Addams Family), and coincidentally in enough time for it to be bought as a Hallow'een decoration (which I have seen a few reviews mention).

 

The house itself is constructed over the course of 3 manuals, with 1 dealing with figures, accessories and the ground floor, manual 2 covering the first floor, and manual 3 the second floor, roof and front gate. This is certainly a good set to own, and is likely to be a collector's piece in the future.

Pros

  • Very similar to the haunted houses seen in the old films and series, such as the Munsters.
  • Reasonable size Haunted House.
  • Good selection of figures, especially the butler and chef.

Cons

  • Sneaky price jack when LEGO knew they were on to a winner.
  • Perhaps a bit too small inside, needed widening so more custom parts can be utilized

Overall, it is a good set to build, taking about 8 hours at a steady pace to construct, and you are well rewarded with a detailed and accurate looking house. Would have been much better value if it had stayed at the original £120 price tag, but greed won in the end when LEGO knew it was likely to be a big success. Unfortunately, the Zombie car offer has now expired, so there is nothing there to soften the blow on your wallet, however the set itself is impressive enough that it should be bearable. Go buy it, you won't regret it.

author: shady_character
title: A haunted Delight
review:
I bought this set at the recent opening of sheffield lego store having only recently rekindled my love for the worlds greatest toy .

It caught my eye when I first seen it appear on the lego site and was eager to get my hands on it come release day. 

Box/Instructions

Box was nicely detailed with several pictures of the build and was nice and full of bricks. the instructions were packed with card to prevent bending and were split into two books .

Parts

This set has a great assortment of parts several of which were new to me (perhaps not to others) . The colour scheme i found suits the set brilliantly. lego have included lots of the new brick pattern bricks in both grey and tan colour ,i guess these will be good for peoples mocs. 

Minifigures

The minifigures in this set include mr and mrs vampyre :) a zombie chef, and two ghosts . The ghosts are of the newer design unlike the old ones that I have from years ago and are greatly improved and glow in the dark really well .The zombie chef is unique to this set and fits in nicely with the kitchen area. The thing I like with the vampyres is the fact that there heads glow in the dark just like the ghosts which was new for me and not seen on any figures previously.

The build

This for me was the best part , having only really build space ships and lego friends this build was a new experience for me and a greatly rewarding one .

Seeing how lego guide you through the build process using clever techniques and varying ways of doing things made putting this model together a joy. I like the way the building hinges and opens like a dolls house ,a feature my daughter loves as she wont leave it alone !! Also the way lego used the tan brick peices in and around the green walls to give the look of rendering coming off and missing add to the effect of this building being run down and derelict ,it really is more impressive to see it in front of you as oppose to in pictures.

The interior of the model is built in tandem with the outside and is nicely detailed using brown pieces to achieve a wooden look to the furniture.

The zombies heads on the exterior supporting beams are a clever and nice touch .

The mini details on the roof and windows add to the creepy feel along with the wonky broken windows and broken paving .

I also added set 30201 (ghost and clock) as the clock fits perfectly in the ground floor room .


My only gripe,as mentioned above is when building the walls ,they can be rather unstable until the reinforcing bricks are added which then stabilise everything but its only a minor issue and as long as your careful you will be fine.

Also the price which started at £120 but soon changed to £150 come release day as its clear lego knew they were onto a winner with this set

The completed model

The finished model is a lego marvel and is currently sitting proud on my table on full display and enjoying the attention its getting ! 

The way the model looks with its creepy wonky tone and clever detailing make this set perfect and will be the centre piece come halloween 

Summary

In my opinion this set is a must for any lego fan as the build, looks and finished model really are awesome ,lego has done a fine job of capturing the derelict creepy haunted look and along with the monster minifigures its a purchase Im glad I made .

author: mablemyhre
title: This is a very nicely detailed haunted house
review: What I like about this set is that it appears to be modeled after the scary house on the hill in Alfred Hitchcock's movie "Psycho".  With over 2000 pieces, I believe it is priced right. The feature that allow you to open the house and see the inside is spectacular.  The minifigs are cool.  I have no complaints.  If you want a Lego set of one of the greatest scary houses of all time, this is it

author: rocao
title: Ambitious and hits most of the marks
review:
10228 Haunted House is the pièce de résistance of the Monster Fighters theme. Comprised of 2064 pieces and with an MSRP of 180 USD, it boasts the third highest piece count and second highest price in the 2012 product lineup. Those gaudy characteristics are usually reserved for the tried and true themes, so having this entry in a newly introduced, likely "one and done" theme oozes ambition. 

Parts

The set consists of 2064 pieces across 209 unique elements. The Bricklink value of all elements (including instructions and sticker sheet) at the time of this review is $373.68. A lot of criticisms of the set are due to its price point, but the value proposition doesn't look so bad by this measure.

Sand green elements are highly desired due to their rarity, and there are ~314 included here, the majority in useful sizes 1 x n brick sizes.

Minifigures

Six minifgures are present, of which Monster Butler and Zombie Chef are exclusive to this set. Unlike the other boxed sets in this theme, there are no Monster Fighters. The monsters are well executed; their expressions are frightening as they should be, yet all the while manage to remain charming. My three year old daughter showed no apprehension playing with them.

It would have been a good idea to include at least one non-monster so that the inhabitants have someone to haunt.

The build

I found the build to be brisk, particularly considering the high piece count. The order of the build was logical, and the steps and corresponding bag parts did not require extensive searching and sorting.

The first items to be built are the minifigures and furniture. This proved to be a great choice for achieving short time-to-value: my young daughter could start playing with these built items within 10 minutes while I proceeded with the rest of the build.

The house is built upon five 8 x 16 plates, rather than on baseplates. This was done to achieve a slightly non-square shape, and to allow the model to hinge open to expose the interior.

I found building up each brick layer of the house walls and assembling the windows was repetitive, but I'm doubtful it could have been approached any other way. The use of masonry bricks for an exposed brick effect did manage to break up some of the monotony.

The furniture -- gramophone, kitchen, in particular -- were interesting to build. The roofing completed the model well. The perimeter wall made clever use of some of the pieces. Beyond that, there were no particularly noteworthy build techniques, and the age rating of 14+ seems pretty conservative. I think the designers missed some opportunities to add some interesting dilapidation to the model. For example, some falling beams, damage to the walls, or sagging to the roof would have added interesting angles and cockeyedness to the build. Instead, they settled with simply slanting the shutters and boards across the windows.

There is a sticker sheet, but thankfully the overall appearance of the model does not suffer if they are not applied.

The completed model

The Haunted House manages to be a beautiful display piece while at the same time offering a good deal of playability. The styling is a faithful reproduction of a Victorian-era haunted house. I could see the figures, floorplan, and furniture, lending itself to hours of play.

Summary

The size and scale of the Haunted House will naturally evoke comparisons with the Modular Series of buildings. In this respect (and in my opinion of course!) it doesn't display as well as a modular building and doesn't have comparable architectural interest. 

However, understanding the differences between the Haunted House and the modulars advances its appreciation. Rather than the stacking floor approach, the Haunted House hinges open. This technique allows for greater playability via increased access, such as simultaneous play between floors, highlighted by the drop down ladder. Though the exterior detailing isn't as intricate as the Modulars, it is detailed on all four sides as opposed to the two sides and heavy focus on the facade of the Modulars.

Ultimately, I applaud LEGO for being ambitious and showing conviction by taking what I perceive as a heightened risk to offer this very large model in an untested theme. I think it is one of the better sets of 2012, just as Monster Fighters is proving to be a surprise hit among themes.

author: DrFrankenstein
title: Impressive and quite unusual LEGO house
review:
The Monster Fighters theme is a joy for kids and adults alike and is shaping in my family's books as the crown jewel of the LEGO 2012 lineup. While The Vampyre Castle (9468) is easily a worthy flagship set for the theme, to everyone's surprise LEGO one-upped it with the Haunted House taking us on a ride through the most iconic set of the monster fiction genre. We enjoyed very much the build and the resulting product which is both an impressive display set as well as a great toy house play set.

Pros

  • Epic build - it's a lot of fun to see the house take shape floor by floor
  • Rich interior and exterior design capture very well the feel of a monster-inhabited Victorian house in  disrepair
  • The doll house hinge system allows the house to maintain realistic look from all angles while still being highly playable on the inside as well
  • Imaginative use of relatively standard bricks in unusual colors tones
  • Nice display set for Halloween

Cons

  • Price - LEGO has firmly positioned this set in the realm of luxury toys
  • Some minor quality issues, which luckily don't detract from the overall experience (occasional variation in the color shades of bricks of the same color; a slightly bent thin beam; flasks included are cheaper versions of the ones shown on the box)

The highly detailed and massive house is brilliant and captures well the feel the look and feel of a classic haunted mansion. While the set is a on the high end price-wise, it more than delivers with its deluxe treatment of the beloved monster house scene. Highly recommended, if you can afford it.

author: 8BrickMario
title: "That one house on the block", sure to terrorize your LEGO City!
review:
This has been a very popular LEGO set, and considered to be the best in the Monster Fighters theme. Many people love the design and have done wonders with it on their own. When I got mine, I took a while to build it, but was I satisfied?

Box/Instructions

The box is appropriately large, and shows off the set quite nicely. The instructions are clear enough, but color distinction was difficult. 

Parts

If you like Sand Green, this set is a gold mine. There are some other nice pieces, like the tall black slopes used on the roofs and the window shutters, and the brick-textured bricks in dark tan. A brown neck bracket and some pearl silver 1x1 tiles also come to mind, as well as the cylindrical heart brick included in the Pirates of the Caribbean theme, and three extra zombie heads used on the house.

Minifigures

There are six minifigures in this set, but two are identical.

Lord Vampyre- The big villain of the theme, Lord Vampyre is essentially a darker version of the Series 2 Vampire. He has two faces, an annoyed scowl, and an angry yell with fangs fully exposed. His torso is very useful for any higher-class character, which is nicely detailed with Edwardian-era attire. 

Vampyre's Bride (Lady Vampyre):

Lady Vampyre (what LEGO should have called her) is a very nice figure. She uses Elizabeth Swann's hair in black, which really adds to her look. Like her husband, she has two faces, but her more neutral face is a wicked grin instead. She has a dark red tattered dress and a blood-drop shaped pendant. Under her dress, the fabric has a disturbingly brain-like pattern.

Monster Butler: In an odd cross between a Zombie and Frankenstein's Monster, the Zombie Butler is nonetheless a good figure. He uses the F. Monster headpiece in grey with black hair and a row of stitches across his forehead. He has a gloomy facial expression and he wears a simple black suit. He has a small serving tray. 

Ghosts: The two ghosts are identical. They use the new wailing shroud, which looks appropriately spooky and sheet-like. Their bodies and heads are completely blank. In this set, they use a brick-and-plate stack in the place of legs. 

Zombie Chef: What an...interesting figure. He looks like a classic chef, but his coat is torn and splattered with red. Yes, LEGO just made an all-but-explicit bloody outfit, though one hopes it's just tomato juice! His face is shared with the Zombie Driver's.

The build

The build took quite a while for me, and I paced myself. The first bag starts off by building the furniture, which is added to the house throughout the rest of the build. Nothing was very difficult or complex...except for the pillars on the front. This section is rather fragile, and aligning the posts/heads with the bricks on top and the plates above is a nightmare I didn't expect to have.

The completed model

Wow. This is a perfect classic HH. It uses the common Victorian style with the central roof tower overlooking the house. The whole exterior is made to look shabby and neglected, with broken shutters, peeling paint, broken and boarded-up windows, spiked railings, and broken stone. The gate section is small and rather insubstantial. I didn't keep it for long. The creepiest detail of the house is the zombie heads topping the pillars in front. That's just wrong! The entire house opens like a doll house (the hinges are concealed in the chimney), and that's where it becomes less interesting. 

The interior pales in comparison to the exterior. Given the detail on the outside, it's forgivable, but the house is rather bare and there isn't enough that says "creepy" inside. In the entranceway, there is a fireplace that's attached to the chimney with a ship-in-a-bottle, which can hinge along the "wall" created by the unfolded chimney. The kitchen contains a simple stove and oven for the Zombie Chef to cook at. A table with a few bottles and a cauldron is next to the side door, and there's a spider web to the left of the stove. Upstairs, the room that the stairs lead to is fairly empty, containing only a writing desk for Vampyre and a small railing.

The bedroom opposite is better, with a spooky wardrobe (containing a bell jar with a heart in it) and a bed with no mattress. Above are some trophy antlers and some gas lamps. There is also a house plant, but the best part of the room is the spooky portraits (stickered) that depict the Monster, Zombie Bride, Werewolf, and Vampyre himself in a limited color palette.

The attic upstairs contains the only action feature in the set. Pull out a hard-to-reach pin on the outside, and a tradoor with a folding ladder drops down. This is a decent feature, and a good way to explain passage to the next floor, but the ladder's reach means that a minifigure would only be able to access it from the other half of the floor, as it comes to the edge of the unfolded room. In the attic is a collection of old things, like a knight's helmet, a rifle, a bone in a jar. There's also a stack of old monster newspapers, which I like. The best interior item is the gramophone, which uses a simple build (a pith helmet is its amplifier!) and there are a few different records to choose from. 

Overall opinion

While I don't feel impressed by the interior of the set, that's easily solved, and the exterior is absolutely fantastic. This set is perfect for any LEGO city, and it's a great home for all of your monster minifigures. If you can still find it, I highly recommend it.
